tit.j: アシナヅチ・テナヅチ

sen.j: アシナヅチ・テナヅチは、日本神話のヤマタノオロチの説話に登場する夫婦神 (神道)である。
sen.e: Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi are couple deities (Shinto deities) that appear in a Japanese legend about the Yamatonoorochi snake.
Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi are a couple of deities (Shinto deities) that appear in a Japanese legend about the Yamatonoorochi snake.
Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi are a couple of deities (Shinto deities) that appear in a Japanese Mythology about the Yamatanoorochi snake.

sen.j: 『古事記』では足名椎命・手名椎命、『日本書紀』は脚摩乳・手摩乳と表記する。
sen.e: In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), the names of these gods are written, respectively, "足名椎命" and "手名椎命" in kanji, while "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) writes them "脚摩乳" and "手摩乳."
In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), the names of these gods are written, respectively, "足名椎命" and "手名椎命" in kanji, while "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) writes them "脚摩乳" and "手摩乳."
In "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), the names of these gods are written, respectively, "足名椎命" and "手名椎命" in kanji, while "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) writes them "脚摩乳" and "手摩乳."

sen.j: 神話の記述
sen.e: The legend
The legend
The Mythology

sen.j: 二神はオオヤマツミの子で、出雲国の斐伊川の上流に住んでいた。
sen.e: Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi were children of Ooyamatsumi and lived in the upper reaches of the Hii-kawa River in Izumo Province.
Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi were children of Ooyamatsumi who lived in the upper reaches of the Hii-kawa River in Izumo Province.
Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi were children of Oyamatsumi who lived in the upper reaches of the Hii-kawa River in Izumo Province.

sen.j: 8人の娘がいたが、毎年ヤマタノオロチがやって来て娘を食べてしまい、スサノオが二神の元にやって来た時には、最後に残った末娘のクシナダヒメを食いにオロチがやって来る前だった。
sen.e: They had eight daughters, but a great snake known as Yamatanoorochi (eight-headed serpent) came to their house every year to eat their daughters, and when Susanoo came to visit the two deities, the snake was about to come to eat Kushinadahime, who was their youngest and last remaining daughter.

They had eight daughters, but a great snake known as Yamatanoorochi (eight-headed serpent) came to their house every year to eat their daughters, and when Susanoo came to visit the two deities, the snake was about to come to eat Kushinadahime, who was their youngest and last remaining daughter.

They had eight daughters, but a great snake known as Yamatanoorochi (eight-headed serpent) came to their house every year to eat their daughters, and when Susano came to visit the two deities, the snake was about to come to eat Kushinadahime, who was their youngest and last remaining daughter.
sen.cmt: Susanoo→Susano他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: 二神はスサノオがオロチを退治する代わりにクシナダヒメを妻として差し上げることを了承し、オロチ退治の準備を行った。
sen.e: Promising to give Kushinadahime to Susanoo as his wife if he could get rid of the Orochi snake, the two deities made preparations to exterminate the snake.
Promising to give Kushinadahime to Susanoo as his wife if he could get rid of the Orochi snake, the two deities made preparations to exterminate the snake.
Promising to give Kushinadahime to Susano as his wife if he could get rid of the Orochi snake, the two deities made preparations to exterminate the snake.
sen.cmt: Susanoo→Susano他ファイルと合わせる

sen.j: スサノオが無事オロチを退治し須賀の地に宮殿を建てると、スサノオはアシナヅチを呼び、宮の首長に任じて稲田宮主須賀之八耳神（いなだのみやぬしすがのやつみみのかみ）（『日本書紀』では稲田宮主神）の名を与えた。
sen.e: Having succeeded in exterminating the Orochi snake and built a palace in a place called Suga, Susanoo called Ashinazuchi and ordered the head of the place to award him the title "Inada no miya nushi sugano yatsumimi no kami" ("Lord of the rice growing country with eight ears"; different kanji are used for the title in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki").

Having succeeded in exterminating the Orochi snake and having built a palace in a place called Suga, Susanoo called Ashinazuchi and ordered the head of the place to award him the title "Inada no miya nushi sugano yatsumimi no kami" ("Lord of the rice growing country with eight ears;" different kanji are used for the title in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki").

Having succeeded in exterminating the Orochi snake and having built a palace in Suga, Susano called Ashinazuchi and ordered the head Suga to award him the title Inada no miya nushi sugano yatsumimi no kami (Lord of the rice growing country with eight ears; different kanji are used for the title in "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki").
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 解説
sen.e: Commentary
Commentary
Explanation

sen.j: 神名には諸説ある。
sen.e: Many theories have been proposed about the names of these gods.
Many theories have been proposed about the names of these gods.
Many theories have been proposed about the names of these gods.

sen.j: 「ナヅ」は「撫づ（撫でる）」、「チ」は精霊の意で、父母が娘の手足を撫でて慈しむ様子を表わすとする説
sen.e: Some people argue that the word "nazu" used in their names means "to caress" and "chi" "holy spirits" and that Ashi (meaning "foot" in Japanese) nazuchi and Te (meaning "hand") nazuchi signify the way in which parents caress their daughters' hands and feet with loving care.

Some people argue that the word "nazu" used in their names means "to caress" and "chi" "holy spirits" and that Ashi (meaning "foot" in Japanese) nazuchi and Te (meaning "hand") nazuchi signify the way in which parents caress their daughters' hands and feet with loving care.

Some people argue that the word 'nazu' used in their names means 'to caress' and 'chi' 'holy spirits' and that Ashi (meaning 'foot' in Japanese) nazuchi and Te (meaning 'hand') nazuchi signify the way in which parents caress their daughters' hands and feet with loving care.

sen.j: 「アシナ」は浅稲（あさいね）で晩成の稲の意、「テナ」は速稲（といな）で早稲の意とする説
sen.e: Others argue that the word "ashina" means "asaine," or late ripening varieties of rice, and "tena" "toina," early ripening varieties of rice.
Others argue that the word "ashina" means "asaine," or late ripening varieties of rice, and "tena" "toina," early ripening varieties of rice.
Others argue that the word 'ashina' means 'asaine,' or late ripening varieties of rice, and 'tena' 'toina,' early ripening varieties of rice.

sen.j: 「畔（あ）の椎」、「田（た）の椎」の対であるとする説
sen.e: There is also a theory according to which these names represent, respectively, "ridge mallets" (a-no-tsuchi) and "field mallets" (ta-no-tsuchi).
There is also a theory according to which these names represent, respectively, "ridge mallets" (a-no-tsuchi) and "field mallets" (ta-no-tsuchi).
There is also a theory according to which these names represent, respectively, 'ridge acorns' and 'field acorns.'
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。ピリオドの位置を変えました。

sen.j: 古語で蛇を「ミヅチ（御づち）」とするように「ヅチ」は蛇を指すことから、「脚無し蛇」「手無し蛇」という手足を持たない蛇の造形を示した蛇神を示しているとする説
sen.e: Still others argue that since the word "zuchi" in old Japanese referred to a snake, as in the word "mizuchi," the names of these gods represent serpent gods named "Ashi-nashi-zuchi" (or a serpent without feet) and "Te-nashi-zuchi" (a serpent without hands).

Still others argue that since the word "zuchi" in old Japanese referred to a snake, as in the word "mizuchi," the names of these gods represent serpent gods named "Ashi-nashi-zuchi" (or a serpent without feet) and "Te-nashi-zuchi" (a serpent without hands).

Still others argue that since the word 'zuchi' in old Japanese referred to a snake, as in the word 'mizuchi,' the names of these gods represent serpent gods named 'Ashi-nashi-zuchi' (or a serpent without feet) and 'Te-nashi-zuchi' (a serpent without hands).

sen.j: スサノオの宮殿があったとされる地には須佐神社 (出雲市)（島根県出雲市）がある。
sen.e: There is Susa-jinja Shrine (Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture) in the place where Susanoo's palace is believed to have existed.
There is Susa-jinja Shrine (Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture) in the place where Susanoo's palace is believed to have existed.
Susa-jinja Shrine (Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture) is located on the supposed site of Susano's palace.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 代々須佐神社の神職を務める稲田氏（後に須佐氏）は大国主の子孫であり、アシナヅチ・テナヅチから数えて2004年現在で78代目であるとしている。
sen.e: The Inada clan (later Susa clan), whose members have been hereditary priests of Susa-jinja Shrine, claim to be the descendents of Okuninushi no mikoto and the 78th generation from Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi as of 2004.

The Inada clan (later Susa clan), whose members have been hereditary priests of Susa-jinja Shrine, claim to be the descendents of Okuninushi no mikoto and the 78th generation from Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi as of 2004.

The Inada clan (later Susa clan), whose members have been hereditary priests of Susa-jinja Shrine, claim to be the descendents of Okuninushi no mikoto and the current priest (as of 2004) is the 78th generation counting from Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 信仰
sen.e: Worship
Worship
Worship

sen.j: 須佐神社のほか、廣峯神社（兵庫県姫路市）、氷川神社 (川越市)（埼玉県川越市）などで祀られている。
sen.e: Apart from Susa-jinja Shrine, these gods are enshrined in shrines such as Hiromine-jinja Shrine (Himeji City, Hyogo Prefecture) and Hikawa-jinja Shrine (Kawagoe City, Saitama Prefecture).
Apart from Susa-jinja Shrine, these gods are enshrined in shrines such as Hiromine-jinja Shrine (Himeji City, Hyogo Prefecture) and Hikawa-jinja Shrine (Kawagoe City, Saitama Prefecture).
Apart from Susa-jinja Shrine, these gods are enshrined in shrines such as Hiromine-jinja Shrine (Himeji City, Hyogo Prefecture) and Hikawa-jinja Shrine (Kawagoe City, Saitama Prefecture).

sen.j: アラハバキとの関係
sen.e: Relationship with Arahabaki
Relationship with Arahabaki
Relationship with Arahabaki beliefs
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 神社関係者が物部の末裔との伝承を持つ埼玉の氷川神社の門客人神社は元々荒脛巾(あらはばき)神社と呼ばれ謎の神アラハバキを祭る神社である。
sen.e: Monkyakujin-jinja Shrine (guest god shrine) in Hikawa-jinja Shrine, whose worshippers are alleged to be descendents of the Mononobe clan, used to be called Arahabaki-jinja Shrine and is dedicated to a mysterious god called Arahabaki.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Monkyakujin-jinja Shrine (guest god shrine) in Hikawa-jinja Shrine, whose worshippers are alleged to be descendents of the Mononobe clan, used to be called Arahabaki-jinja Shrine and is dedicated to a mysterious god called Arahabaki.

Monkyakujin-jinja Shrine (guest god shrine) in Hikawa-jinja Shrine in Saitama Prefecture, whose worshippers are alleged to be descendents of the Mononobe clan, used to be called Arahabaki-jinja Shrine and is dedicated to a mysterious god called Arahabaki.

sen.j: ここにはなぜかアシナヅチ、テナヅチの２神がアラハバキと共に奉られている。
sen.e: For some unknown reason, the Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi gods are enshrined in this shrine along with Arahabaki.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For some unknown reason, the Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi gods are enshrined in this shrine along with Arahabaki.
For some unknown reason, the Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi gods are enshrined in this shrine along with Arahabaki.

sen.j: 物部の本来の祭神とも言われ、祟り神として神話に現れる三輪山のオオモノヌシが蛇神とされた。
sen.e: The Oomononushi god of Mt. Miwa (Nara), which allegedly was originally worshipped by the Mononobe clan and appears in legends as an evil god, is believed to have been a serpent god.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Oomononushi god of Mt. Miwa (Nara), which allegedly was originally worshipped by the Mononobe clan and appears in legends as an evil god, is believed to have been a serpent god.
The Omononushi god of Mt. Miwa (Nara), which allegedly was originally worshipped by the Mononobe clan and appears in mythology as an evil god, is believed to have been a serpent god.

sen.j: また物部の聖地であった大阪四天王寺の地にアラハバキ信仰の痕跡が残る。
sen.e: There is also evidence to suggest that the Arahabaki god may have been worshipped in Shitennoji in Osaka, which was the Mononobe clan's sacred land.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is also evidence to suggest that the Arahabaki god may have been worshipped in Shitennoji in Osaka, which was the Mononobe clan's sacred land.
There is also evidence to suggest that the Arahabaki god may have been worshipped in Shitennoji in Osaka, which was the Mononobe clan's sacred land.

sen.j: そのため、オオモノヌシ＝アラハバキ説がある。
sen.e: From these facts, some people argue that Oomononushi is the same as Arahabaki.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: From these facts, some people argue that Oomononushi is the same as Arahabaki.
From these facts, some people argue that Omononushi is the same as Arahabaki.

sen.j: この氷川神社の謎からさらにヤマタノオロチとアラハバキ、そして物部の関連が指摘されることがある。
sen.e: The mystery about Hikawa-jinja Shrine has also led some people to discuss possible relationships between Yamatanoorochi, Arahabaki and the Mononobe clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The mystery about Hikawa-jinja Shrine has also led some people to discuss possible relationships between Yamatanoorochi, Arahabaki and the Mononobe clan.
